text: Again the resentment was widespread and the results disappointing a tax estimated to yield 50,000 in fact raised only 27,000. In the following year, 1380, the last most notorious third poll-tax was agreed by a Parliament which met at Northampton. There were dark reasons for a meeting so far away from the capital in a town with poor communications and not over with hostelries and lodgings.
